creator: SteveMann
title: Real Augmented Reality™: Burnerphone and other phenomenal realities
description: This project creates 'Real Augmented Reality' art by capturing and 'burning' the radio waves emitted by an old phone into a piece of wood using a laser cutter. The resulting artwork visually represents the invisible radio waves emitted by the phone, creating an augmented reality experience without the need for special glasses or devices. The phone is then mounted onto the wood in the exact location the waves were initially captured.
steps: Get an old phone working long enough to transmit a signal.

Capture the phone's waveform using a SWIM (Sweeping Wavelength Interference Meter) setup. This involves a reference antenna, a moving antenna connected to a Lock-In Amplifier (LIA), and photographing the sweep with a light source in a dark room.
Ensure the wave is recorded from the location where the artwork will be hung to capture reflections and other environmental effects.
Process the photograph of the waveform by negating it and scaling it to 1:1. Verify that the scale matches the calculated wavelength of the phone's signal (5.6cm per cycle for a 5.8 GHz signal).
Transfer the waveform to the laser cutter software, ensuring the scale is accurate.
Burn the waveform into the wood using the laser cutter. Position the wood so that the smoke stains enhance the visual appeal of the waveform.
Drill holes in the wood to mount the phone. Attach the phone to the wood using stiff wire, positioning it in the same location where the original recording was made.
Hang the finished artwork in the location where the waveform was originally captured.
